However, most of the catalytic processes involve the heat release or absorption effect, which would influence the catalytic efficiency and even result in the deactivation of the catalyst. Recently, phase change materials (PCMs) have demonstrated unique potential for enhancing the catalytic process in thermocatalytic, photocatalytic, biocatalytic and electrochemical fields due to the thermal management and energy storage functions. Microencapsulation technology enables the in-situ coupling of PCMs within catalysts, and the introduction of encapsulated shells or nanoparticles with catalytic effects endows the PCMs with good chemical stability, thermal cycling stability as well as high thermal conductivity. The synergistic mechanism between catalysts and PCMs in different systems can be summarized as self-stored thermal driven catalysis, in-situ temperature regulation and heat flow/electron synergistic effect. In addition, the correlation between the microstructure and catalytic/thermal management performance of PCMs@Catalysts composites was systematically discussed. Finally, the current challenges and development trends of the multifunctional PCMs@Catalysts composites are also presented. The review aims to highlight recent advances in phase change materials for enhancing the catalytic process and provide insights into the rational design and controllable preparation of PCMs@Catalysts composites. Graphical Abstract The PCMs@Catalysts can be used to raise energy efficiency and enhance the catalytic process in thermocatalytic, photocatalytic, biocatalytic and electrochemical fields by incorporation of the thermal management and energy storage functionalities. Keywords Phase change materials Catalyst Microencapsulation Catalytic performance Synergistic mechanism 1 Introduction Catalysis is one of the most essential technologies for supporting the global economy [1] and improving the quality of human life [2], which is essential for the development of chemical [3,4], petroleum [5,6], agricultural [7] and pharmaceutical sectors [8]. Catalysts are required for the production of over 90% of chemicals in the industry [9], and the global demand for catalysts will grow at an annual rate of 3.7% in the next three years [10,11]. However, catalytic reactions are generally associated with heat absorption and release phenomenon, which would lead to uncontrollable temperature fluctuation and catalyst deactivation, and cause serious waste of energy [12]. Therefore, the control of reaction temperatures and the prevention of heat loss is of great importance in enhancing the catalytic process. Thermal-storage material is capable of storing energy through its phase change or chemical reaction and has emerged in the field of catalysis in recent years [13–16]. As an essential branch of thermal-storage materials, phase change materials (PCMs) could undergo the phase transition process at a constant temperature and absorb/release large amounts of latent heat, offering the advantages of high energy storage density and free of pollution [17–20]. Generally, PCMs do not have the catalytic function, and therefore need to be coupled with catalysts to fabricate PCMs@Catalysts composites with integrated structures. When PCMs and catalysts are applied to the reaction system as separate entities, the PCMs could not efficiently adsorb the heat released from the catalytic reaction, control the temperature of the catalytic sites or drive the catalytic process due to the high thermal resistance and low heat transfer rate [21]. While the tight combination of catalyst and PCMs allows for the efficient and timely transfer of heat generated by the reaction. Fig. 1 displays the applications of PCMs@Catalysts in photocatalysis, thermal catalysis, biocatalysis, and electrochemistry fields. Among them, PCMs@Catalysts are always used for oxidative degradation and reduction reactions in photocatalysis; The applications of PCMs in thermal catalysis mainly include thermal reactors, methanation and polymerization reactions; PCMs coupled with metal metal nanoparticles show excellent catalytic activities in bacterial inactivation and also can be used in the preparation of high-capacity capacitors and battery packs. In high-temperature industries, fuel combustion generally requires heat sources to drive the reaction. However, the flue gas generated during the reaction extracts a large amount of heat, and the residual heat is insufficient to drive the chemical equilibrium shift [22]. It is an effective method to rely on PCMs with high enthalpy to absorb the waste heat from the exhaust gas and adjust the chemical equilibrium shifts. The strong exothermic effect of chemical reactions often results in uneven temperature distribution [23] and localized hot spots of the catalyst bed [24], leading to the altered product distribution and reduced activity and lifetime of catalysts. The phase change process of PCMs at a constant temperature helps prevent the temperature fluctuation of the catalytic bed and thermal energy dissipation [25]. For photocatalytic reactions, the low quantum yield [26], easy recombination of photogenerated electron-hole [27] and low utilization of solar energy [28] would limit the widespread application of photocatalysts. When the PCMs are combined with photocatalysts, PCMs with solar-to-thermal energy storage ability could promote the thermal movement of substrates and reduce the recombination of photogenerated charges. Moreover, PCMs with thermal-storage functions have been applied to electrochemical fields. Irreversible Joule heat and reversible heat caused by entropy changes are generated in electrochemical devices [19]. The superimposed effect results in the accumulation of considerable heat and an increase in ambient temperature inside the device, which accelerates aging and shortens its lifetime. In addition, due to the kinetic and thermodynamic properties of biochemical reactions, most biocatalysts are thermosensitive and only exhibit high catalytic activity in the optimal temperature range [29]. The precise temperature control of PCMs protects electrical components from the thermal shock during the charging/discharging process and provides biocatalysts with optimal temperature range, contributing to enhanced cycling and catalytic performance of the catalysts. PCMs@Catalysts composites have been developed and applied in the past decade (Fig. 2 ). Initially, the composites were used in thermocatalytic reactors to enhance the methanol oxidation process [30]. The PCMs cores can absorb a large amount of heat generated by exothermic reactions to prevent local thermal runaway and deactivation of the catalyst. Since 2015, PCMs@Catalysts composites obtained by encapsulating PCMs with metal oxide-based photocatalysts have been widely used in photocatalytic fields, including dyes degradation [31], sterilization [32] and reduction of organics [33]. From 2018 to 2020, the introduction of conductive polymers and metal oxides on the PCMs microcapsules imparts composites with excellent electrochemical performance [34,35]. The thermoregulatory effect of PCMs mitigates the thermal shock of the heat from the redox reaction on electrodes. In the last two years, metal nanoparticles, enzymes, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) immobilized on the surface of microcapsules enabled the application of PCMs@Catalysts composites in biocatalytic applications, including bactericidal [36], organics decomposition [37] and detection of toxicants [38,39]. Although previous reviews on microcapsule PCMs have described their preparation methods, characterization techniques, thermal properties and application in thermal management and thermal energy storage fields [40–43], this paper aims to give an overview of PCMs@Catalysts composites and highlight recent advances in PCMs for enhancing the catalytic process. First, the synthesis strategy of PCMs@Catalysts composite is introduced. Then the application of PCMs in different catalytic fields is summarized, including thermal catalysis, photocatalysis, electrochemistry and biocatalysis. We also emphasize the synergistic mechanism of PCMs@Catalysts composite in enhancing the catalytic process: (1) self-stored thermal driven catalysis: PCMs can efficiently absorb the heat during the catalytic process. After removing the reaction heat source or light source, PCMs release latent heat continuously and steadily to drive the continuation of reactions [44,45]. The mechanism is mainly applied for thermocatalytic and photocatalytic reactions; (2) in-situ temperature regulation: PCMs can keep themselves at a constant temperature during the heat absorbing/releasing process if it is undergoing the phase change process, thus in-situ regulating the temperature and avoiding the deactivation of the active sites [34,35]; (3) heat flow/electron synergistic effect: The synergistic effect of latent heat released by PCMs and photogenerated electrons/holes formed in conduction band (CB)/valence band (VB) helps to overcome the reaction energy barriers and enhance the oxidation for substrates [46–48]. The mechanism is suitable for photocatalysis. Finally, we also proposed some perspectives for applying PCMs in catalytic fields and discussed technical challenges for future development of the PCMs@Catalysts composites towards the enhanced catalytic process. 2 Synthesis strategy of PCMs@Catalysts composite To reduce interfacial thermal resistance between PCMs and catalysts, and solve the leaking problem of PCMs during its solid-liquid transformation process, PCMs usually need to be encapsulated with functional shells before using in the catalytic process. The functional shell efficiently prevents the leakage of the liquid-phase PCMs and also serves as a transition layer to in-situ support the catalytically active materials to achieve the integration of PCMs and catalysts. Sometimes the functional shell possesses active catalytic sites, further enhancing the synergistic effect of the PCMs and catalyst. In this review, we named the functional shell supporting other catalysts and the functional shell itself with catalytic active sites both as catalytic shells. Microencapsulation is a method of preparing PCMs@Catalysts composite by encapsulating solid-liquid PCMs with catalytic shells [49]. This technique has the advantages of good morphological/thermal stability and high mechanical strength [32]. It should be noted that confining PCMs into the inner pores of porous matrixs by various interactions such as surface tension, capillary forces, van der Waals forces or hydrogen bonding is another strategy to combine the PCMs and catalysts [50]. However, in contrast to microencapsulation, the PCMs in the pores of porous materials may occupy the active sites, and cause pollution of reaction system or equipment corrosion. The different types of solid shells endow the PCMs with various advantages. For example, the inorganic shell layer is the most used functional shell in PCMs@Catalysts composites due to its fast thermal response rate [49]. The in-situ coupling of catalytic shells with PCMs allows for the absorption/release of thermal energy while participating in the catalytic reaction, thus accelerating chemical reaction and realizing efficient energy utilization. The main preparation process of PCMs@Catalysts composites reported in the literature is shown in Fig. 3 below, including the physical method and chemical method. 2.1 Physical method Physical methods are less commonly used in the preparation of PCMs@Catalysts composites. The physical method is the process of mechanically concentrating the PCMs cores in microcapsule shells, mainly including spray drying and air suspension. The spray drying method is achieved by atomizing the mixture formed by the PCMs cores and the shell solution in the hot air stream. The air suspension method consists of the following steps: the PCMs cores are dispersed and suspended by airflow, and then the dissolved/melted shells are sprayed onto the cores using the atomizing nozzle, where the shell molecules settle on the surface of the cores and form shells with uniform thickness [51,52]. 2.2 Chemical method 2.2.1 Interfacial polymerization method Interfacial polymerization is the most common method used to prepare PCMs@Catalysts composites. First, the emulsifiers are neatly applied to the surface of the PCMs cores to form stable oil-in-water (O/W) or water-in-oil (W/O) micelles; subsequently, the precursor molecules of the shell are uniformly dispersed around the micelles and polymerized under initiation; finally, the polymer network formed on the surface of the PCMs cores, which is macroscopically represented as microencapsulated PCMs with the dense shell [53]. Additional methods are required to introduce catalytic materials on the surface of the primary microcapsules. Liu et al. [54] anchored graphene on the surface of n-eicosane@TiO2 by a surface self-assembly method to enhance the photocatalytic activity of PCMs@Catalysts, where graphene was attached to the surface via hydrogen bonding (as shown in line 1 of Fig. 3). Sun et al. [55] synthesized a PANi/CNTs electrochemical layer on the surface of microencapsulated n-docosane by the in-situ oxidative polymerization method, and its electroactivity was greatly enhanced (as shown in line 2 of Fig. 3). Jiang et al. [37] modified the surface of TiO2/Fe3O4 hybrid shell, and subsequently achieved the immobilization of Candida rugosa lipase on the shell by covalent bonding. 2.2.2 In-situ precipitation method The in-situ precipitation method is to form a self-assembled system at the interface between oil and water based on emulsion-template systems, in which metal ions are attracted onto the surface of PCMs micelles by electrostatic interactions [56]. The type of surfactants and the balance between precipitation and deposition of inorganic precursors are two key factors affecting the fabrication of PCMs@Catalysts. Li et al. [31] used the in-situ precipitation method to prepare multifunctional microcapsules with a ZnO shell that exhibited good bactericidal activity. In addition, Liu et al. [57] combined the interfacial polymerization method and in-situ precipitation method to make CdS precipitate on the surface of n-eicosane@SiO2 microcapsules. 2.2.3 Suspension polymerization method The PCMs cores, polymer monomers, and initiators form a mixed oil phase suspended in the water phase, and then initiators trigger the polymerization of monomers to form a shell layer [58]. The microcapsules prepared by this method are pure and uniform in size. Ma et al. [59] used ultrasonic polymerization to obtain Sn microspheres coated with polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) shells. Subsequently, CaCO3 shell and Ce/Mn active sites were introduced onto the surface of microspheres through the self-assembly technique and solution combustion synthesis method (as shown in line 3 of Fig. 3). 2.2.4 Heat oxidation/induced oxidation method Dense oxide shells of PCMs@Catalysts are generally generated by the thermal oxidation process when using high-temperature alloys as the PCMs cores. Nomura et al. [60] obtained MEPCMs with dense α-Al2O3 shells by boehmite treatment and thermal oxidation for Al-Si alloy microspheres. Li et al. [45] and Tian et al. [61] introduced Ni particles on the surface of Al-Si alloy microspheres to induce and accelerate the formation of α-Al2O3 shell, which was then supplemented by co-precipitation method to achieve the combination of catalysts and PCMs (as shown in line 4 of Fig. 3). 2.2.5 Sol-gel method Sol-gel method is a chemical method of preparing PCMs@Catalysts composites. The process uses the hydrolysis of metal alkoxide compounds to form a sol-gel system, followed by the polymerization between gel particles to generate microcapsules with three-dimensional networks [62,63]. Chai et al. [64] added tetrabutyl titanate precursors to O/W emulsions of n-eicosane to prepare PCMs@Catalysts for dyes degradation and sterilization, which TiO2 shells formed in the sol-gel process. Pornea et al. [65] deposited TiO2 shell layers on the surface of SiO2-coated n-eicosane microcapsules through the sol-gel deposition of titanium isopropoxide. Zong et al. [66] prepared Ce-Eu/TiO2 hollow microspheres by the sol-gel method and then encapsulated decylic acid-palmitic acid into the hollow microspheres by vacuum impregnation (as shown in line 5 of Fig. 3). 3 Enhanced performance of PCMs@Catalysts in thermal catalytic fields The combination of PCMs and catalysts shows a promising prospect in the high-temperature industry by reducing industrial waste heat dissipation and achieving efficient heat utilization. The application field includes fuel combustion [45], methane decomposition and reforming reactions [67,61], flue gas selective reduction, desulfurization, denitrification [59] and so on (Fig. 4 ). The effect of PCMs in high-temperature catalytic processes mainly involves self-stored thermal driven catalysis mechanism and in-situ temperature regulation mechanism. To drive high-temperature reactions by utilizing the waste heat, alloy powders and molten salts with high enthalpy are widely used as the PCMs cores. In addition, micron-scale PCMs could effectively shorten the heat transfer distance and promote the PCMs to absorb heat generated by the active sites of catalytic materials, thus preventing the thermal runaway of catalysts in the catalytic bed. Table 1 describes the preparation methods, microphysical properties and applications of PCMs@Catalysts applied in thermal catalysis. 3.1 Fuel synthesis The PCMs@Catalysts composites can be applied in the preparation process of fuel, which plays a positive role in saving energy by utilizing waste heat. Ni/ceramic/molten-salt composite catalyst was prepared and used in the solar thermochemical reforming process of methane. Ni species were loaded on porous alumina or zirconia spheres by the conventional impregnation method and then molten NaCl and Na2CO3 were immobilized in the porous microstructure of the ceramic spheres by capillary/surface tension. The essential problem in the solar thermochemical reforming of methane is the instability of catalytic reaction temperature caused by fluctuating incident solar radiation. The exothermic process of molten salts (NaCl and Na2CO3) with high latent heat could effectively avoid the rapid temperature decrease of the catalyst bed and promote the continuation of subsequent catalytic reactions. In the simulated 4-day solar operation, the methane conversion was maintained at 100%, and the H2/CO ratio of the produced gas was almost kept at 0.74 when Ni/alumina/NaCl was used as catalysts [67]. CO2 reforming of methane was a process in which methane/CO2 were independently resolved into CH2* and O* and then recombined with each other. The adsorption and dissociation of CO2 occurred as a precursor through the electron transfer of Ni species on the surface of alumina spheres, and Ni species provided the possibility for the ionization resolution of methane/CO2 and the acquisition/release of free electrons [68,69]. CO2 methanation is the most sustainable way to utilize CO2 as a resource [70]. The use of PCMs to absorb the heat from the highly exothermic CO2 methanation is an effective measure to avoid damage to the catalyst from heat. Takahashi et al. [71] prepared micro-encapsulated PCMs (MEPCMs) by subsequent boehmite treatment, precipitation treatment and thermal oxidation treatment. Then they used the impregnation method to load Ni catalysts on the surface of MEPCMs directly. There was no breakage or collapse of the Ni-loaded MEPECMs when storing or releasing heat, and the composite exhibited higher CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity than commercially available α-Al2O3 particles in the methanation reaction. Micron-scale MEPCMs allowed for rapid melting of the Al-Si alloy and speeding up the thermal response. MEPCMs covered with NiO particles on the surface could remove the heat generated on the catalyst surface at a rate of 2.5 MW·m−3 during the exothermic reaction, inhibiting the abrupt temperature rising of the catalyst bed, as shown in Fig. 5(A) . Fig. 5(B) shows the temperature programs of the Ni/MEPCMs catalyst during the CO2 methanation reaction. Compared to catalysts without thermal storage function, Ni/MEPCMs started to store heat via phase transition when the reaction temperature exceeded the melting point of PCMs, which could prevent the thermal runaway of catalysts. 3.2 Fuel combustion A large amount of heat released from fuel combustion in the industry may lead to uneven temperature distribution of the catalytic beds or deactivation of the catalytic sites [72]. The design and development of PCMs@Catalysts composites contribute to solving the mentioned problems. Li et al. [73] prepared thermal storage functional catalysts by an innovative yolk/shell strategy to encapsulate PCMs with catalytic shells. The Al2O3 shell was obtained by thermal oxidation of Al microspheres induced by Ni nanoparticles under the air atmosphere. Then Al@Al2O3 was coated with Fe2O3/Al2O3 using a gelation method to form (Fe2O3/Al2O3)/(Al@Al2O3) heat storage functional oxygen carriers (Fig. 6(A) ). The step-by-step oxidation process generated abundant voids inside the capsule, providing enough space for volume changes during the phase change process and allowing the catalyst to exhibit good cycling performance in the melt-solidification cycles. This rapid melting of the PCMs component also effectively optimized the temperature distribution of catalyst bed in exothermic reactions, which could be applied to chemical looping processes and integrated coal gasification fuel-cell combined cycles and other unsteady-state chemical processes (Fig. 6(B)). Li et al. [45] combined Co3O4 with SiAl@Al2O3 to prepare thermal storage functional catalyst Co3O4/(SiAl@Al2O3) by induced oxidation method and co-precipitation method (Fig. 6(C)). The encapsulated PCMs coupling Co3O4 realized the efficient catalytic combustion of lean methane and helped to improve the thermal runaway and hot spot problems in the catalyst bed. The dynamic coupling effect between the in-situ thermal management of PCMs@Catalysts and methane combustion promoted the continuous progress of methane combustion reaction. After turning off the heat source for 37 minutes, the methane conversion catalyzed by Co3O4/(SiAl@Al2O3-30 wt%) can still reach 50%. Tian et al. [61] prepared Al@Al2O3 MEPCMs covered with Ni nano-layers on its surface by induced oxidation method (Fig. 6(D)), which Ni nanoparticles could facilitate the oxidation of Al spheres (20–50 μm) to Al2O3. Subsequently, Ni species catalyzed the decomposition of CH4, and carbon generated on the surface of Al@Al2O3 composites to form Al@Al2O3-C composites. The dropwise addition of ammonium hydroxide during the preparation process contributed to the deposition of more Ni species on the surface of Al spheres, leading to the higher thermal conductivity of the composites and better catalytic performance for CH4 conversion. The MEPCMs after carbon deposition showed no change in phase change behaviors after 100 heating/cooling cycles. The high thermal conductivity (8 W/(m·K)) and phase transition enthalpy (266 J/g) endowed the MEPCMs with a very promising application for the high-temperature catalysis industry. The preparation process of the MEPCMs mentioned above includes liquid-phase and solid-phase reactions. The surface modification and introduction of catalyst are achieved in the liquid-phase process, and the dense shell layer forms during the solid-phase reaction. In fuel combustion applications, the synergistic principle of PCMs and catalytic materials could be summarized as self-stored thermal driven catalysis and in-situ temperature regulation. Al-Si alloy microspheres with high phase change enthalpies can prevent the rapid increase of catalyst bed temperature during its endothermic process, and the exothermic process provides sufficient heat for fuel combustion. 3.3 Fuel-cell combined cycle Latent heat storage (LHS) technology based on PCMs has been applied to the utilization of solar energy and industrial waste heat at relatively low temperatures [74]. Nomura et al. [60] synthesized Al-Si alloy microspheres with AlOOH shell by boehmite treatment, and then obtained α-Al2O3-coated Al-Si alloy microcapsules by thermal oxidation treatment (Fig. 7(A) ), which broadened the application of LHS technology in the fuel-cell field. The boehmite-treated AlOOH film was a bilayer structure consisting of a dense inner layer and a porous fibrillar outer layer, which was converted into an α-Al2O3 shell layer during the heating process. This dense inner layer could effectively resist the corrosion caused by the internal liquid metal at high temperatures. The developed MEPCMs with high heat transfer rates and high heat storage density (247 J/g) showed great promise in energy storage and thermochemical reactions. The functional MEPCMs combined with catalysts were used for advanced chemical processes by transferring the heat generated from exothermic reactions to endothermic reactions, such as advanced integrated coal gasification fuel-cell combined cycle (A-IGFC), advance integrated coal gasification combined cycle (A-IGCC), and super integrated coal gasification fuel-cell combined cycle (S-IGFC) (Fig. 7(B)). IGFC combines coal gasification technology with fuel cell power generation, including coal gasification, syngas purification, fuel cell power generation, exhaust gas combustion and waste heat recovery systems [75]. PCMs@Catalysts have been developed to facilitate the recovery of waste heat and solve the problem of insufficient combustion of exhaust gas. PCMs@Catalysts, which consists of MEPCMs coupled with metal oxide catalysts (such as Co3O4, NiO, CeO2) [76–78], could be applied to the recovery of industrial waste heat and the subsequent catalytic combustion of low-temperature exhaust gas. The synergistic effect between PCMs and catalytic components was the self-stored thermal driven catalysis mechanism. After saving industrial waste heat, the released process heat from PCMs promoted the reaction between adsorbed tail gas and the active lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface to produce carbon/nitrogen oxides, and reduced the activation energy of the oxidation reaction. The lattice oxygen in the catalyst was consumed by the gas molecules and reduced to the oxygen vacancy and was replenished by the oxygen vacancy activation [79]. In addition, the heat released by PCMs also increased the lattice oxygen mobility at the interface between PCMs and metal oxides, to achieve efficient catalytic oxidation of tail gas molecules. 3.4 Industrial denitrification/desulphurisation Acidic and harmful gases such as nitrogen and sulphur oxides produced by the combustion of fossil fuels exacerbate environmental pollution. Industrial denitrification/desulphurisation is an effective way to eliminate acidic gas pollution. Ma et al. [59] fabricated a thermal storage functional catalyst with thermal expansion voids using a “double-layer coating, sacrificing inner layer” method, which significantly increased the high-temperature thermal energy storage capacity. Firstly, methylmethacrylate (MMA) was polymerized on the surface of Sn microspheres to form a PMMA layer by ultrasonic polymerization method. Subsequently, the CaCO3 shell layer was synthesized on the surface to encapsulate microcapsules by self-assembly method. The PMMA layer was decomposed during the calcination process and produced certain voids between the Sn microspheres and the CaCO3 shell layer. Such voids could alleviate the broken problem of metal PCMs due to the volume expansion during the heating process. Finally, Ce and Mn species were loaded into microcapsules by solution combustion synthesis/vacuum impregnation. Multifunctional porous composite phase change materials (CPCM) were also applied in low-temperature SCR (selective catalytic reduction) reactions and other catalytic reactions (100–300 °C). Mn-containing catalysts exhibited unique performance in low temperature denitrification due to the variable chemical valence, good migration ability of the active lattice oxygen and abundant surface acidity. The Ce/Mn sites of ceramic CPCM played a positive role in catalyzing NO x /SO x , and the PCMs inside could alleviate the thermal runaway problem of the catalytic reaction as well as improve the temperature distribution inside the reactor. This preparation method achieved an effective combination of sensible and latent heat materials. 3.5 Adsorption/conversion of hazardous substance Molecular imprinting is an effective method to utilize selective sites in polymers to match target molecules with precise and selective recognition [80]. Niu et al. [81] successfully constructed imprinted phase-change microcapsules (MIMs) by microencapsulating n-eicosane with SiO2 layer using emulsion-template interfacial condensation method, followed by surface free-radical polymerization using bisphenol A (BPA) as a template molecule to coat the polymer surface layer. Such recognition sites were fabricated on the surface of MIMs by using BPA as a template molecule and MAA as a functional copolymer monomer. In this paper, this methodology was used to adsorb organic pollutant BPA molecules. The carboxyl groups in the polymer layer interacted with BPA by hydrogen bonding and formed preassembled complexes. Thus, BPA molecules could be selectively adsorbed onto MIMs assisted by the recognition sites, and the adsorbed BPA molecules could be easily removed from the poly(EGDMA-co-MAA) layer using a strongly polar solvent. The phase change process of PCMs provided the driving force for the adsorption and desorption of BPA. During the elution process, the heat release process of n-eicosane in MIMs promoted the removal of BPA, while the heat absorption process during the rebinding process facilitated the binding of selective sites to BPA. The adsorption capacity of MIMs for BPA was much higher than that of nonimprinted phase change microcapsules (NIMs). The MIMs synthesized in this paper provided promising prospects for precise adsorption and catalysis of hazardous substances in wastewater. 3.6 Polymerization/esterification reaction The in-situ temperature regulation function of PCMs is critical in regulating the thermal behavior of exothermic reactions. The development of PCMs@Catalysts composites contributes to enhancing the catalytic process and solving the problems of catalysts in various areas, including easy deactivation, short working life and poor cycling performance. Microencapsulation technology effectively realizes the in-situ coupling of catalytic materials and PCMs, while preventing easy leakage and improving the thermal property of PCMs. The combination of PCMs cores with different phase change behaviors and multifunctional organic/inorganic shells broadens the applications of PCMs@Catalysts composites in catalytic fields. Currently, photocatalysis is the most widely used field of PCMs@Catalysts. The coupling of alkane PCMs with catalysts (such as MOFs, COFs) is expected to exhibit well prospects in other photocatalytic reactions. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) are common photocatalytic reactions. However, insufficient sunlight utilization and low quantum efficiency severely limit the photocurrent transfer rate of HER and CO2RR reactions, thus making them difficult for industrial applications. The photothermal conversion performance of PCMs helps to solve the problems of discontinuous and low intensity of sunlight exposure in industrial production. The heat released from PCMs can accelerate the thermal movement and improve the distribution of photogenerated charges on the catalyst surface, thus enhancing the migration rate of photocurrent and quantum efficiency. In summary, we predict that PCMs will show brighter prospects in various catalytic fields in the near future. The paper reviewed recent research advances in PCMs@Catalysts and analyzed the synergistic mechanisms between phase change components and catalytic components, which were summarized in the following points: (1) Self-stored thermal driven catalysis: PCMs can store energy from the heat source in the catalytic reaction or accumulating heat by absorbing sunlight before the reaction. After removing the heat or light source, the PCMs continuously and steadily release latent heat to drive the catalytic reaction. For thermal catalysis, PCMs@Catalysts composites are generally required to store large amounts of latent heat to drive highly exothermic reactions such as fuel combustion. In photocatalytic reactions, PCMs@Catalysts should possess photothermal absorption capabilities to convert sunlight into required heat. (2) In-situ temperature regulation: The in-situ coupling of PCMs cores and catalytic shell layers could absorb the heat during the redox reaction and regulate the microenvironmental temperature. In thermal catalysis, the in-situ effect avoids the deactivation of active sites due to high temperature, while tailoring the catalyst bed temperature to prevent thermal runaway. For electrochemical reactions, the in-situ cooling effect of PCMs effectively lowers the ambient temperature of supercapacitors to extend the service life. The in-situ thermal buffering effect of PCMs occurs simultaneously with the biocatalytic reaction and prevents denaturation of the enzyme biocatalysts on the surface of multifunctional shells. (3) Heat flow/electron synergistic effect: The heat flow released by the PCMs cores could be applied towards overcoming the energy barrier for reactants conversion, accelerating the thermal movement and direct photochemical conversion of reactants on the catalyst surface; Photogenerated electrons and holes formed in CB and VB react with O2 and H2O respectively, producing superoxide and hydroxyl radicals for oxidizing substrates; The synergistic effect of heat flows and photogenerated electrons in PCMs@Catalysts composites helps to enhance the utilization of the solar energy and the conversion for reactants in photocatalytic reactions. In general, the catalytic performance and thermal storage capacity of the PCMs@Catalysts composites are influenced by the shell layer thickness, surface properties, specific surface area, pore size distribution and the amount of active components. Multifunctional shells grew on the surface of PCMs inevitably increase the thickness of PCMs@Catalysts composites, thus reducing the phase change enthalpy. But too thin shell layers lead to a significant decrease in the mechanical properties. Therefore, achieving the simultaneous enhancement of catalytic performance and phase change behavior while ensuring the mechanical properties is the key to current research on PCMs@Catalysts composites. This paper focused on the effects of PCMs in enhancing chemical reaction rates and improving microenvironmental temperatures, and provided good theoretical guidance for the application of PCMs in catalysis. But the microstructure of the PCMs@Catalysts, such as pore size, surface functional groups, shell thickness and crystallinity, is still subject to further investigation on the mechanisms affecting the catalytic and energy-storage performance. Finally, the in-situ coupling of PCMs with other catalysts (e.g. organobase catalysts, rare earth catalysts, zeolite catalysts, etc.) will significantly facilitate the large-scale application of PCMs@Catalysts in industrial and domestic fields. However, there are many challenges to this topic, including rational design and precise construction. The reasonable selection of PCMs and catalysts and the construction of hierarchical-structure PCMs@Catalysts composites are therefore crucial to solving the above problems. coredata.dc:description: Catalysis plays a critical role in almost every industrial process, and developing high-performance catalyst is one of the most efficient strategies for enhancing the catalytic process. However, most of the catalytic processes involve the heat release or absorption effect, which would influence the catalytic efficiency and even result in the deactivation of the catalyst. Recently, phase change materials (PCMs) have demonstrated unique potential for enhancing the catalytic process in thermocatalytic, photocatalytic, biocatalytic and electrochemical fields due to the thermal management and energy storage functions. The innovative integration of PCMs and catalysts can simultaneously raise energy efficiency and enhance the catalytic process. Microencapsulation technology enables the in-situ coupling of PCMs within catalysts, and the introduction of encapsulated shells or nanoparticles with catalytic effects endows the PCMs with good chemical stability, thermal cycling stability as well as high thermal conductivity. The synergistic mechanism between catalysts and PCMs in different systems can be summarized as self-stored thermal driven catalysis, in-situ temperature regulation and heat flow/electron synergistic effect. In addition, the correlation between the microstructure and catalytic/thermal management performance of PCMs@Catalysts composites was systematically discussed. Finally, the current challenges and development trends of the multifunctional PCMs@Catalysts composites are also presented. The review aims to highlight recent advances in phase change materials for enhancing the catalytic process and provide insights into the rational design and controllable preparation of PCMs@Catalysts composites.
